title: 108_hr811
content: The Act may be cited as the "Student Medical Access Raising Test Scores Health Act" or the "SMARTS Health Act". The Congress finds that protecting children's health requires a caring adult and a connection to school. Schools are vital for community support and promoting health. Primary care and behavioral health services are crucial for children's well-being. School safety and violence prevention are essential, and good health is necessary for optimal learning. School safety, violence prevention, and early intervention are crucial for student well-being. Good health is essential for academic success, with schools promoting access to medical and mental health care. Children are facing increasing rates of behavioral and physical illnesses, including ADHD, asthma, diabetes, and obesity. New prevention strategies should be community-based. Effective health services in schools can prevent future diseases. Effective school-based health programs must focus on improving behavioral and physical health, including addressing obesity. Schools are ideal settings to provide care for children with limited access to health services, which contributes to the growing rates of disease among children. Prevention strategies should be combined with treatment to reduce illness rates and the need for treatment. Higher disease rates, even with adequate access to health services, lead to loss of vitality and increased disease complications. Community-based prevention programs are essential for reducing disease incidence. School-based health programs should focus on improving behavioral and physical health, including addressing obesity. Effective community-based prevention programs result in significant savings to the Federal Government and States by reducing health services expenditures. Savings from prevention efforts should be reinvested in further prevention programs and not redirected to unrelated purposes. Prevention programs that achieve savings should not have their funding reduced. DEMONSTRATION GRANTS FOR EXPANSION OF SCHOOL-BASED HEALTH PROGRAMS. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may provide demonstration grants to eligible entities to expand school-based health programs. Eligible entities include public or nonprofit private institutions of higher education or local educational agencies. Coordination with various health programs is required. The Act focuses on health disparities and provides grants to eligible entities like public or nonprofit institutions of higher education or local educational agencies to expand school-based health programs. These programs offer preventive and behavioral health services, including nutrition and physical activity, in coordination with other community health, education, or social service providers. The Act provides grants to eligible entities like universities and educational agencies to expand school-based health programs in various states, including Maryland, Texas, New Mexico, California, and Connecticut. The Act provides grants to universities and educational agencies to expand school-based health programs in different states, such as Connecticut and Illinois. Grants can only be made if an application is submitted to the Secretary with necessary information. The Secretary establishes health outcome goals based on Healthy People 2010 for the children served by the program. Evaluations and reports are required for the program. The Secretary will conduct evaluations of school-based health programs funded by grants to assess if they meet goals, increase access to health services, improve children's health, and reduce disease rates. A report with findings and recommendations for a national program will be submitted to Congress by December 31, 2004. The Secretary will provide recommendations for a national program to establish and operate school-based health programs, including funding amounts and potential savings in health services programs. Definitions for "institution of higher education" and "local educational agency" are provided. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2003 through 2008.
